question: What effect do earthworms have on the nutrient content of topsoil?

content.source_1: Earthworms function as decomposers: by ingesting dead plant material and soil organic matter, they mineralize nutrients and excrete casts enriched in plant-available nitrogen and phosphorus.
content.source_2: Decomposer activity generally increases nutrient availability in soil by converting complex organic compounds into inorganic forms accessible to plants.
content.source_3: As earthworms burrow through the upper soil, they mix soil and distribute their nutrient-rich casts across the topsoil, tending to homogenize and spread nutrients near the surface.
content.source_4: Many anecic and endogeic earthworms translocate organic matter downward—dragging surface litter into burrows and depositing casts belowground—thereby moving carbon and nutrients from the topsoil surface into deeper layers.
content.source_5: Accelerated decomposition and bioturbation by earthworms can increase nitrate production and water infiltration, promoting leaching losses that reduce nutrient pools in surface soils in earthworm-invaded forests.
content.source_6: Empirical studies in northern temperate forests report that earthworm invasion thins the organic horizon and lowers carbon and nitrogen stocks in the topsoil, indicating net depletion of surface nutrients.

answer: by adding nutrients to the topsoil
